facts.description: Uranus is the seventh planet from the Sun and has the third-largest diameter in the solar system. It is a cold, windy world with a unique sideways rotation, making it one of the most unusual planets in the solar system.

size.comparison: If Earth were the size of a nickel, Uranus would be about as big as a softball.

orbital.eccentricity: Uranus follows a near-circular orbit around the Sun.

rotation.sunrise_sunset: Because of Uranus' extreme tilt, its poles experience 21-year-long days and nights.

temperature.description: Uranus has one of the coldest atmospheres in the solar system, with temperatures even lower than Neptune in certain regions.

environment.potential_for_life: Uranus' extreme temperatures, pressures, and volatile composition make it highly unlikely to support life as we know it.

surface.features: As an ice giant, Uranus doesn't have a solid surface. Its outer layers are made up of swirling icy materials like water, ammonia, and methane.
surface.appearance: The planet appears blue-green due to methane in the atmosphere absorbing red light and reflecting blue.

moons.description: Uranus has 28 known moons, named after characters from the works of William Shakespeare and Alexander Pope.

rings.description: Uranus has 13 faint rings, with the outermost ones colored blue and red, and the inner rings mostly dark grey.

magnetosphere.description: Uranus' magnetic field is irregularly shaped, tilted nearly 60 degrees from the planet's axis and offset from the center. The magnetosphere extends into space in a corkscrew shape due to the planet's sideways rotation.

formation.description: Uranus formed around 4.5 billion years ago from gas and dust. It likely migrated to its current position in the outer solar system from a closer orbit.

namesake.mythology: Named after Uranus, the Greek god of the sky, as suggested by Johann Bode. It was the first planet discovered using a telescope.
